Does not generate full project scaffolding
Does not execute build commands or deployment

best_practices: Always await params and searchParams in page components - they are Promises in Next.js 16
Use proxy.ts instead of middleware.ts for request filtering and authentication
Store UTC timestamps and convert to local time only for display
Add default.tsx to all parallel routes to prevent 404 errors during soft navigation
anti_patterns: Do not use synchronous params - they will show [object Promise] in rendered output
Do not create middleware.ts in Next.js 16 - it will be ignored
Do not pass datetime-local values directly to APIs without converting to UTC
Do not load web component scripts afterInteractive - they need beforeInteractive

faq.question: Is this skill compatible with Next.js 15?
faq.answer: No, this skill focuses on Next.js 16 patterns. Next.js 15 uses synchronous params while Next.js 16 requires awaiting params and searchParams.

faq.question: What is the maximum project size this skill supports?
faq.answer: The skill provides patterns for projects of any size. Large applications should follow modular architecture with route groups and proper code splitting.

faq.question: How does this integrate with MCP tools?
faq.answer: The skill references Next.js DevTools MCP for runtime diagnostics and can be combined with Context7 for official documentation lookup.

faq.question: Does this skill access or store any data?
faq.answer: No, this is a documentation-only skill. It provides patterns and code examples without executing any code or accessing external systems.

faq.question: Why is my page showing [object Promise]?
faq.answer: You are not awaiting the params Promise in Next.js 16. Always use `const { id } = await params` before accessing values.

faq.question: How does this compare to using the official Next.js documentation?
faq.answer: This skill provides curated patterns with common mistakes highlighted. It complements official docs by focusing on production-ready implementations.
